meanings.definition: not filled or occupied; available to be used:

meanings.definition: a body part that has stopped being used and has almost disappeared:
examples: They are vestiges of the Wolffian duct, one of the embryonic structures that precedes the development of the adult generative organs.

meanings.definition: a small part left from something larger and more important, esp. one that is no longer used:
examples: Vestiges of ancient settlements can be seen in the caves.

meanings.definition: being a small remaining part or amount

examples: a vestigial organ/limb/tail

meanings.definition: in a way that has almost disappeared, or that is a small remaining part of something:
examples: He failed to show the battlefield bravery that is vestigially expected of men.

meanings.definition: a process giving employees the right to keep the shares, pension plans, etc. given to them by a company after working there for an agreed period:
examples: He took in $19 million from the vesting of stock awards he had received in previous years.

meanings.definition: the office where a vet works:

meanings.definition:

meanings.definition: to examine something carefully to make certain it is suitable, correct, etc.:

meanings.definition: a person who has had a lot of experience in a particular activity or job:

meanings.definition: a person who was once a member of the armed forces

meanings.definition: connected with taking care of the health of animals:

formal for

meanings.definition: the root of vetiver, which has a strong smell and is used, for example, to make perfume (= a liquid with a pleasant smell) :
examples: Vetiver is a common scent in men's cologne.

meanings.definition: an official power or right to refuse to accept or allow something:
examples: The president has the power of veto over any bill that comes across his desk.

meanings.definition: to refuse to allow something:
examples: In 1961, President De Gaulle vetoed Britain's entry into the Common Market.

meanings.definition: the power to refuse to allow something to be done, or such a refusal:

meanings.definition: to refuse to allow something to be done:
examples: The governor said she would veto the bill unless certain parts were changed.

meanings.definition: an official power or right to refuse to accept or allow something even if most of the other people or organizations involved approve of it:

presidential veto
the power/right of veto

meanings.definition: to refuse to allow or accept something such as a vote even if most of the other people or organizations involved approve of it:

meanings.definition: to cause difficulty to someone, or to cause someone to feel angry, annoyed, or upset:
examples: This issue looks likely to continue to vex the government.

meanings.definition: to cause someone to feel annoyance or trouble:
examples: The question that vexes Ben the most is, "Why me?"

meanings.definition: worry or anger:
examples: After several unsuccessful attempts to start his car, he swore in vexation.

meanings.definition: something that is worrying or annoying
difficult to deal with and causing a lot of anger, worry, or argument:
examples: This settlement will resolve one of the most vexatious problems in the field of industrial relations.

meanings.definition: having little chance of succeeding in law, but intended to annoy someone or cause problems for them:
examples: The amendment opens the door to vexatious litigation.

meanings.definition: vexatious legal complaints are not serious but are annoying to deal with:
examples: 70% of firms thought more employees were bringing weak and vexatious claims against their employers.

meanings.definition:
→

meanings.definition: in a way that is annoying or difficult to deal with :
examples: The results of his efforts were vexatiously few.

meanings.definition: difficult to deal with and causing a lot of disagreement and argument:
examples: Economists argue over the vexed question of how to reduce spending.

meanings.definition: troubling and difficult:

meanings.definition: annoying, worrying, or causing problems :
examples: The shortage of qualified teachers remains a vexing problem.

meanings.definition: in a way that is annoying or worrying, or that causes problems:

meanings.definition: written abbreviation for very good condition: used in advertisements to describe goods that are not new but that are in very good condition:

meanings.definition: abbreviation for very high frequency: radio waves between 30 to 300 MHz:

meanings.definition: abbreviation for Video Home System: a system for video recorders used at home
going through or stopping at a place on the way to another place:

meanings.definition: using a particular machine, system, or person to send or receive something:

meanings.definition: by way of, or by use of:

meanings.definition: ability to work as intended or to succeed:
examples: Rising costs are threatening the viability of many businesses.

meanings.definition: ability to continue to exist or develop as a living being:
examples: As the world population of Hawaiian geese has shrunk to very small numbers, the bird's continuing viability is in doubt.

meanings.definition: the degree of chance that something will succeed:
examples: Her role was to assess the viability of investment options overseas.

meanings.definition: able to work as intended or able to succeed:
examples: In order to make the company viable, it will unfortunately be necessary to reduce staffing levels.

meanings.definition: able to continue to exist as or develop into a living being:

meanings.definition: able to exist, perform as intended, or succeed:
examples: The company had to seek other ways to remain viable.

examples: Rising oil prices have made alternative energy sources more economically viable.

meanings.definition: in a way that is able to succeed or to work as intended:
examples: The challenge to me as a manufacturer is to run the company viably.

meanings.definition: in a way that is able to continue to exist or develop into a living being:

meanings.definition: a long, high bridge, usually held up by many arches, that carries a railway or a road over a valley:

meanings.definition: a high bridge that carries a road or railroad over an area that is difficult to cross, such as a deep valley, very wet land, or the steep side of a hill:

meanings.definition: a brand name for a drug for treating men who are impotent (= who cannot have sex because their penis cannot become or stay hard)
a small glass bottle, especially one containing liquid medicine
a small bottle used to hold a liquid:
examples: The store gave away vials of their new perfume.

meanings.definition: items of food:
examples: The table was laden with the choicest viands.

meanings.definition: relating to the sale of life insurance policies sold by a dying person to someone else at a price lower than the value of the policy:
examples: The viatical investor paid $80,000 for the $100,000 life insurance policy.

meanings.definition: the mood of a place, situation, person, etc. and the way that they make you feel:

examples: A vibe check is a way to measure someone's mood, especially if they are giving out bad vibes.

meanings.definition: the quality of being energetic, exciting, and full of enthusiasm:

meanings.definition: (of light or colour ) the quality of being bright and strong:

meanings.definition: energetic, exciting, and full of enthusiasm:

a vibrant personality

meanings.definition: Vibrant colour or light is bright and strong:

meanings.definition: energetic, bright, and full of life or excitement:

meanings.definition: in a way that is energetic, exciting, and full of enthusiasm:

meanings.definition: a title sometimes given to the Pope (= the leader of the Catholic Church)

examples: The owner of a motor vehicle is vicariously responsible for injuries even though he is not driving the car.

meanings.definition: the quality of being vicarious (= experienced through the activities of other people, rather than by doing something yourself):

meanings.definition: a tool with two parts that can be moved together by tightening a screw so that an object can be held firmly between them while it is being worked on:

meanings.definition: a moral fault or weakness in a person’s character:

meanings.definition: in the UK, the person in charge of a college or university

meanings.definition: the job or period of being a vice president (= a person responsible for the president's duties if they cannot do them) of an organization such as a club:
examples: Friction led to his resignation from the club's vice-presidency.

meanings.definition: the person who has the position immediately below the president in some countries, and who is responsible for the president's duties if he or she is unable to do them:

meanings.definition: the person who is responsible for a large, important part of a company or organization:

meanings.definition: the elected official immediately below the president who is elected with the president every four years

examples: This is Jeff Walton, our VP of Finance.

meanings.definition: someone in charge of one of the main parts of an organization:

meanings.definition: the politician directly below the president of the US
a group of people involved in immoral illegal activities, especially illegal sex or drugs:

meanings.definition: a special group of police officers whose job is to stop crimes that involve sex and drugs

meanings.word_type: noun[ C usually singular or U ]
meanings.definition: the position or office of a vicegerent (= a person who represents God on earth or who represents a ruler or other person with authority), or the area that they rule over:

meanings.definition: involving a ruler or other person with the job of representing a king or queen, especially in a colony (= a country controlled by another country):
examples: The crowd marched towards the viceregal palace, but the viceroy was absent.

meanings.definition: relating to a colony (= a country controlled by another country), or to its culture:

meanings.definition: the job of being viceroy (= a ruler representing a king or queen, ruling for them in another country), or the period when someone is viceroy:

meanings.definition: a soup made with potatoes, leeks, and cream, often eaten cold
the area around a place or where the speaker is :

meanings.definition: the area immediately surrounding something:

meanings.definition: in a way that is cruel and shows an intention to hurt or upset someone:

meanings.definition: a person or organization that buys shares cheaply in companies that are failing in order to take control, improve their performance, and so make money:
examples: Bonds of troubled companies can offer profits to so-called vulture investors.

meanings.definition: a person or organization that buys a company’s or country’s debt that has not been paid and takes legal action to get them to pay it:
examples: Vulture investors are taking advantage of the rise in foreclosures.

meanings.definition: the parts of the female sex organs that are outside the body
relating to the vulva (= the parts of the female sex organs that are outside the body):
examples: The risk of developing vulval cancer increases as you get older.
They are running randomized clinical trials in the treatment of vulval pain.

meanings.definition: a long simple musical instrument that produces a single loud note and is blown by South African football supporters at games
